channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Peaceful Mountain Town in Western Canada Is Shaken by Deadly Shooting
item.description: Tumbler Ridge sits at the foothills of the Rocky Mountains in northeastern British Columbia, and is surrounded by expansive mountain ranges and a geological park.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Prosecutors Fail to Bring Charges Against Democrats Involved in Illegal Orders Video
item.description: The rejection was a remarkable rebuke, suggesting that ordinary citizens did not believe that the lawmakers had committed any crimes.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona and the other five Democratic lawmakers had posted a video that enraged President Trump by reminding active-duty members of the military and intelligence community of their obligation to refuse illegal orders.

item.title: Trump Wants to Revive Shipping. Investors Are Slow to Back Him.
item.description: A French logistics behemoth promised $20 billion for the United States, but a year into President Trump’s second term, only a fraction of the money has arrived.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He’s going to be investing $20 billion into the United States because of the election,” President Trump said last year when Rodolphe Saadé, the chief executive of the shipping company CMA CGM, visited the White House.

item.title: Before Trump Blasted U.S.-Canada Bridge, Owner of Competing Span Lobbied Administration
item.description: A Detroit billionaire met with Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, hours before President Trump said he would block the opening of a new bridge connecting Detroit to Canada, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Gordie Howe International Bridge (Detroit, Mich and Windsor, Ontario)
item.media:description: President Trump said on Monday he would block the opening of the Gordie Howe International Bridge, currently under construction to link Detroit with Windsor, Ontario.

item.title: House Defeats Republican Bid to Block Votes on Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Three Republicans joined Democrats in rejecting a bid by G.O.P. leaders to continue skirting a law that requires the House to vote promptly on measures challenging President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: House Republicans had shielded their members from having to choose between supporting tariffs many of their constituents opposed and angering President Trump by voting to cancel them.

item.title: ‘No Reason He Should Have Died’: Alex Pretti’s Parents Open Up
item.description: In their first sit-down interview, Michael and Susan Pretti avoided recriminations and recalled the son that Michael called “an exceptionally kind, caring man.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:description: “The truth is, he was an exceptionally kind, caring man,” Michael Pretti said of his son, Alex.

item.title: Top Border Official Praised Agent Who Shot Chicago Woman, Evidence Shows
item.description: A Border Patrol agent shot Marimar Martinez five times, claiming that she tried to run him over. Newly released videos and text messages reveal fresh details about what happened.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Illinois
item.media:description: Body camera footage from the shooting of Marimar Martinez in Chicago in October.

item.title: Don Lemon Hires Federal Prosecutor Joseph H. Thompson in Minneapolis Church Protest Case
item.description: Facing charges over his role at a church protest, Mr. Lemon, a journalist, retained a veteran litigator who recently resigned from the U.S. attorney’s office in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Journalist Don Lemon outside federal court in Los Angeles last month.

item.title: Away From Pomp of Olympics, Homeless Shiver on Streets of Milan
item.description: Six homeless people have died in the Italian city in recent weeks, highlighting the widening inequality as the Games unfold there.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers helping a homeless person at the Garibaldi station in Milan on Sunday.

item.title: Former Palm Beach Police Chief Said Trump Told Him ‘Everyone’ Knew About Epstein in 2006
item.description: Michael Reiter, a former Palm Beach police chief, described a 2006 conversation with Donald Trump to the F.B.I. years later, according to a newly released document.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: The former police chief’s account highlights the inconsistent statements President Trump has made over the years about his relationship with both Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: Lutnick Acknowledges Traveling to Epstein’s Island
item.description: The commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, acknowledged at a Senate hearing that he and his family visited Jeffrey Epstein on his private island.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, testifying before the Senate Appropriations Committee at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Peter Attia’s Ties to Epstein Spark a Backlash From Doctors
item.description: What started as a rebuke of Dr. Attia has become a discussion about his credentials, longevity medicine and whom patients should trust.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Epstein Files Reveal Efforts to Build Ties With Russian Officials, Including Putin
item.description: New documents detail Jeffrey Epstein’s efforts to foster strategic, sometimes reciprocal relationships with Russian officials.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: The latest released files show that Jeffrey Epstein had hoped to facilitate a meeting with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: F.D.A. Refuses to Review Moderna Flu Vaccine
item.description: The vaccine maker’s shots involve the successful Covid vaccines’ RNA technology. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has broadly rejected it, canceling millions of dollars in research projects.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Moderna is a pioneer in using mRNA technology, first with the Covid vaccine. Its flu shot was being developed for people 50 and older.

item.title: Climate Change Is Erased From Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence for Judges
item.description: After Republican criticism, a group that offers professional resources to judges withdrew a climate science chapter from its Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Chevron v Natural Resources Defense Council (Supreme Court Decision)
National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine
item.media:description: J.B. McCuskey, the West Virginia attorney general, in Washington last month. He led the effort against the climate chapter in the judges’ handbook.

item.title: Behind the E.P.A.’s Rush to Repeal the Endangerment Finding
item.description: The agency is racing to repeal a scientific finding that requires it to fight global warming. Experts say the goal is to get the matter before the justices while President Trump is still in office.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, at the agency’s headquarters in Washington last year.

item.title: Mexican Cartel’s Seized Ammunition Is Traced to U.S. Army Plant
item.description: About 137,000 .50-caliber rounds have been seized since 2012, and of those, 47 percent came from a plant in Kansas City, Mo., Mexico’s defense secretary said.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer in Villa Unión, Mexico, with a .50-caliber cartridge. Mexico’s defense secretary said that about 137,000 .50-caliber rounds had been seized since 2012.

item.title: Man Accused of Killing His Father Said He Was on a ‘Mission From God’
item.description: In a courtroom in Ireland, prosecutors detailed the rambling, manic confessions of Henry McGowan, the New York man charged with murdering his father in a luxury hotel.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/PA Images via Getty Images
item.media:description: Henry McGowan of New York City is on trial in Ireland, accused of murder in the death of his father.

item.title: A Desperate Father, a Troubled Son and Death in a 5-Star Hotel
item.description: Henry McGowan headed for Europe, showing signs of mental distress. His father, John McGowan, raced after him. This week, the son will stand trial in Ireland, accused of his father’s murder.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman

item.title: Hong Kong Activist Anna Kwok’s Father Convicted of National Security Crime
item.description: In her first interview about her father, the exiled Hong Kong activist Anna Kwok said the authorities were targeting her family to try to silence her.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Anna Kwok testifying during a hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., in 2023.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show and the Everyday People Who Made It Authentic
item.description: A priest from Sacramento. A bar owner from New York. A taquero from Los Angeles. Puerto Rico came alive at the Super Bowl because of hundreds of non-famous performers.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Britney Spears Sells Her Song Catalog
item.description: The pop hitmaker, who hasn’t released a new album in 10 years, sold the rights to her music to Primary Wave.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Britney Spears has sold tens of millions of albums and scored five No. 1 hits on Billboard’s Hot 100 singles chart.

item.title: Dissidents Are Silenced, and the West Moves On
item.description: On Jimmy Lai and the future of freedom.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A.I. May Put Progressives to the Test
item.description: The left needs a sharper A.I. politics.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; source photographs by Cavan Images and feedough/Getty Images

item.title: Late Night Mines Trump’s Million Mentions in the Epstein Files
item.description: “A million times? There’s not even that many references to Hamlet in the play ‘Hamlet,’” Jordan Klepper said on “The Daily Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: California Man Sentenced to 4 Years for Covert Work on China’s Behalf
item.description: The man, Mike Sun, corresponded with Chinese government officials, monitored the visit of Taiwan’s president to California and backed the election of a city council member, according to court documents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, who was then the president of Taiwan, came to California in 2023. During her visit, she met with Kevin McCarthy, a California Republican who was the speaker of the House at that time.

item.title: Baboon Sibling Rivalry Suggests Monkeys Feel Jealousy Like People
item.description: Young primates in a southern African nature park were observed to constantly interfere when their mother was giving attention to a younger brother or sister.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: Ford Says Electric Vehicle Losses Will Continue for 3 More Years
item.description: Ford Motor reported a big loss for 2025 because of its troubled electric vehicle division, which it has significantly scaled back.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: An F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck, which the company stopped producing last year, after federal tax credits for electric vehicles ended.

item.title: Elon Musk Wants to Build an A.I. Satellite Factory on the Moon
item.description: In a meeting with employees at his company xAI, Mr. Musk revealed a vision for a facility that includes a giant catapult to launch his satellites into space.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Elon Musk told employees of xAI that he plans to put a factory on the moon as a steppingstone to colonizing Mars.
